description: From Middle English joye, borrowed from Old French joie, from Late Latin gaudia, neuter plural (mistaken as feminine singular) of Latin gaudium (“joy”), from gaudēre (“to be glad, rejoice”). Doublet of jo and gaudy (“Oxford college reunion”). Displaced native Old English ġefēa.

entries.meaning: A feeling of extreme happiness or cheerfulness, especially related to the acquisition or expectation of something good.
examples: a child's joy on Christmas morning

entries.meaning: Anything that causes such a feeling.
examples: the joys and demands of parenthood

entries.meaning: Luck or success; a positive outcome.
examples: Grant had no joy with taking a nap, so he began to systematically feel if everything was working: fingers and toes, etc.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The sign or exhibition of joy; gaiety; merriment; festivity.

description: From Middle English joyen, joȝen, joien, from Old French jöir, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: joy (third-person singular simple present joys, present participle joying, simple past and past participle joyed)

examples: I joy to see you wear around your neck the holy relic I bestowed on you;—but what Moorish charmlet is that you wear beside it?

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To give joy to; to congratulate.
(transitive, obsolete) To gladden; to make joyful; to exhilarate.
